title: Planning documents not on the public site for reference 16/03443/DEXRG

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
For background, a large single storey extension (24.5278 sqm) along a party wall with neighbour completed in 2014 without planning permission, granted a decision of regularisation in January 2017 (reference 16/03443/DEXRG), and with further adaptions to the ground floor living space to add a downstairs toilet and open plan living, increased ground floor footprint by around 85% when compared with the original property footprint. At the same time, a side extension some 8.8258 sqm was constructed, which included the moving of a soil drainage pipe from an upstairs bathroom (and which does not form part the regularisation decision. No supporting documents are available on the planning site for reference 16/03443DEXRG, other than dates and notes which are out of step with the reality of the building position at that address, and even with relaxation of the planning process, the extension was more than double the allowable 3x3m and built along a shared party wall.
Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I am seeking the following information:
1.	For 16/03443DEXRG, Please supply all documents (both email, paper, digital) for this application, for example copies of application, architect plans, safety certificates re the quality of the building work, surveyors report/assessment of building regulation standard for the extensions ie were they assessed specifically for suitable noise insulation (across all walls, floors and ceilings of rooms adjoining party walls (including the extension and main house) given size of extensions and open plan modification.
2.	Please supply any internal planning department documents (email, written, digital, notes of meetings) that exist in relation to this reference 16/03443DEXRG, and which may not have been included in part one above. Please include any documentation on decision making and factors that were taken into consideration (for example, (but not an exhaustive list) checks on sound proofing, building over drains, moving of waste/sewage pipes and approvals from a relevant organisation to tap into the main drainage etc).
3.	Prior to giving retrospective approvals in this case, was there a consultation with the impacted neighbours (sharing the party walls), to discuss quality/noise impacts or any other such concerns.
4.	Was there any declaration of interest between any officials involved in the approval/assessment and decision making in this case and the householders or their wider family circle?
Yours faithfully,
Amanda Fenn

Dear Amanda Fenn,
Internal Review – Reference – FOI / 2022-23-1202
Thank you for your email of the 27/03/2023, in which you requested a
review of Sheffield City Council’s response to your Freedom of Information
request. We endeavour to provide a response to internal reviews within 20
working days. However, a review can sometimes be delayed and I apologise
for the considerable amount of time you have had to wait for a response to
be provided.
I can now confirm that a full and impartial review of the decision made in
this case has been conducted with a summary as follows:
You contacted the council on 20^th January 2023 with the following
request:
Please supply the following information:
1.           For 16/03443DEXRG, Please supply all documents (both email,
paper, digital) for this application, for example copies of application,
architect plans, safety certificates re the quality of the building work,
surveyors report/assessment of building regulation standard for the
extensions ie were they assessed specifically for suitable noise
insulation (across all walls, floors and ceilings of rooms adjoining party
walls (including the extension and main house) given size of extensions
and open plan modification.
2.           Please supply any internal planning department documents
(email, written, digital, notes of meetings) that exist in relation to
this reference 16/03443DEXRG, and which may not have been included in part
one above. Please include any documentation on decision making and factors
that were taken into consideration (for example, (but not an exhaustive
list) checks on sound proofing, building over drains, moving of
waste/sewage pipes and approvals from a relevant organisation to tap into
the main drainage etc).
3.           Prior to giving retrospective approvals in this case, was
there a consultation with the impacted neighbours (sharing the party
walls), to discuss quality/noise impacts or any other such concerns.
4.           Was there any declaration of interest between any officials
involved in the approval/assessment and decision making in this case and
the householders or their wider family circle?
I have reviewed your complaint and have determined that firstly, your
information request should have been logged under the Environmental
Information Regulations. Secondly, the Council is in breach of the Code of
Practice which requires a response to an internal review within 40 days
and we have taken almost a year to reply. We sincerely apologise for this
but we have had a significant backlog of requests that is taking us a long
time to get through.
I am pleased to attach a number of documents that Sheffield City Council
hold on the matter.
Please note that personal data has been redacted under Regulation 12(3) of
the Environmental Information Regulations 2004 (EIR) and Regulation 13 EIR
as amended by Sch. 19, para 307 of the Data Protection Act 2018, which
provide an exception for where the information requested includes personal
data of which the applicant is not the data subject where disclosure would
contravene the data protection principles of the General Data Protection
Regulation (GDPR). Disclosure of the information would contravene the data
protection principle under Article 5(1)(a) of the General Data Protection
Regulation that processing of personal data must be fair, lawful and
transparent.
12(5)(e) of the Environmental Information Regulations 2004 (EIR) provides
an exception for the confidentiality of commercial information where such
confidentiality is provided by law to protect a legitimate economic
interest. The information is subject to confidentiality provided by law.
There is a duty of confidence that the council owes those submitting
building control applications.
Regulation 12(5)(e) is subject to the public interest test set out at
regulation 12(1)(b). Therefore, the Council must consider whether, in all
the circumstances of the case, the public interest in maintaining the
exception outweighs the public interest in disclosing the withheld
information.
Furthermore, regulation 12(2) of the EIR requires a public authority to
apply a presumption in favour of disclosure when relying on any of the
regulation 12 exceptions.
The public interest in disclosure is transparency and accountability.
The public interest in withholding the information is the harm to the
commercial interests of Sheffield City Council and to the general public
who may disengage with the process if they believe their confidentiality
is broken when they submit an application under Building Regulations.
The public interest in maintaining the exception outweighs the public
interest in disclosure. This is because, the withheld information retains
a commercial sensitivity, and it would not be in the public interest for
information to be disclosed which would prejudice the Council’s efforts to
achieve a fair and competitive tender process. A Building Control
application is submission between the applicant and the authority and
unlike Planning Applications are not within the public domain.
In reaching this decision we have relied upon the guidance from the
Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO). The ICO is the independent
regulator of public authorities application of information rights law. The
guidance is
here: [1]
https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/com...
